The scary thing is .. this could kill hundreds of millions if not billions.

A shortage of medical supplies, reduced transport, no running water, no heating, no electricity, no communications and no transport of or refrigeration of food.

For at least a few years society would be a mess. You'd have cities at first go dark and after a few days riots and mass chaos due to shortages of resources.

You'd also end up with oil shortages.

Even cars turned on could be fried.

Cities could collapse into chaos. In towns and villages they'd be confused for weeks and have limited communication with big cities and then they'd end up seeing soooo many people fleeing cities to their rural less urban areas for food etc.

Governments would try to prioritize generators for hospitals and civic buildings.

Military would have to be deployed on streets to mantain order. A martial law for a long period. Curfews. Starvation, increased disease.

By the time we have the entire world grid restored .. hundreds of millions or more will be dead.

Also you can bet huge war between nations would break out over resources. Imagine china struggling and turning on Mongolia or Russia turning on the EU.

It would take years to rebuild the power grid and replace the lost technology but it could take 25 years for the economy and social order to fully return to normal.

We need to have emergency protocols in place at places of government where if NASA or the ESA get a few minutes notice of a huge solar flare incoming that within a minute power stations as many as possible can be shut down. No power for a few hours but then they can be turned back on. If not shut down before we are hit they won't ever turn back on, they'll need rebuilding.

Its not even a question of if we get hit by a big one .. it's when. It could be in 2025 or 2050 or 2090 but it's coming and could be soon.

Two problems:
1. You said that CMEs don't effect our bodies.
But, SuspiciousObservers found several articles on how changes to the solar magnetic fields bothers animals and humans.

2. Are we ready for a CME?
I hope so. President Trump ordered the electric grid operators to harden their equipment that serves critical infrastructure, such as military bases. It is not too hard to do: add dc current sensors (Hall Effect transducers) and protective relay logic that is looking for a quasi-dc ground current. If the summation of dc current pulses lasts longer than 1 minute, trip the breakers or switches that normally connects this transformer to the grid. Backup protection option: put temperature sensors on the magnetic core and transformer frame. If either gets too hot, trip the breaker or switch.
Leave the breaker tripped for at least 10 minutes, then evaluate whether it is safe to close.
Why trip the breaker? The quasi dc causes overheating, which damages the insulation, resulting in a short circuit, causing a fire. The transformers that are high priority for this protection are huge. The waiting list for building one of these is NORMALLY 9 months or more. If we have many of these transformers fail at the same time, then WOW!!! How long will it take to build just the biggest, most important transformers? Shutting down the grid for 10 minutes is not as disruptive as 9+++ months.

I am a Retired Professional Engineer, electrical protection. The US Military is concerned about this.

I was sleep deprived and hadn't eaten, and was having a terrible day. Then while driving (around 6:30pm) I see a shimmering light in the sky. I quickly recognize it's an Aurora, and pull over imediately. Luckily I was next to an open field, and the night sky was clear, so I got an absolutely breathtaking view of it. I have always been fascinated by the Aurora and had always wanted to see one, so this event turned a really horrible day into one of the best ones in my life. Looking forward to seeing more in the winters to come! ^_^

According to their measurements that is. And there was a timeline actually that points out towards 2040. My information is second hand from someone that actually was related to an engineer working for nasa. Now fast forward to now, and actually go into the governments web site that actually publishes data for research of solar activity and you will see that the activity that would lead to such catastrophe has been steadily moving towards a possible scenario in the near future… isn’t that crazy???

What’s even more interesting about the unstable sun activity currently is that if you read the data and correlate it to actual outages around the world it actually will surprise you how time after time it coincides with the irregular solar activity. Steve McGreevy captured perhaps the most brilliant recordings of ELF radiation of dawn chorus and whistlers. You can find his recordings by googling his name and ELF. In 2000 I designed and constructed my own ELF receiver with a mic level output to feed into at that time my new 4mm DAT recorder. When the K7-level CME swept past us 11/12 April 2001, I stood outside for two hours recording spectacular ELF radiation. The solar wind dynamic pressure peaked near 30 nPa, solar wind speed near 700 km/s, magnetic field near 8 nT. Whistlers, multi-hop whistlers, TE’s, and pulsating auroral hiss. The most spectacular sounds are the Dawn Chorus Steve McGreevy recorded. They are mystical in effect: organic, as the sounds of wind howling through leafless tree branches, birds, frogs in the springtime. There is a whole world of the ‘sound’ of invisible life in the ELF spectrum.

In 2008 or 2009, I was sitting in my apartment surrounded by my old computer, the tower, the big monitor, my stereo and speakers, my electric guitar, my guitar amp, everything plugged in and on. A lightning storm was raging outside and suddenly there was a boom that I can't even describe, and this slow-motion "wave" went through me. I later described it to my coworkers as feeling like every atom in my body was shifted apart like a bead curtain; I felt like I was being expanded and lifted, all in slow-motion. To this day, I think it was an EMP from a bolt that struck nearby, but there were no alarms set off, no fires, and I haven't been able to find anything online. After about a minute of reflection and checking that I was ok and could move, I turned my attention back to my electronics and everything was gone. The guitar still works to this day, but I lost everything else.

Then finally the great sweeping ages of animals, the amphibians, the dinosaurs, at last the mammals, each one enduring millions on millions of years, great dynasties of creatures rising, flourishing, dying away -- all this against a background of continuous and violent upheaval. Mountain ranges thrust up, eroded away, cometary impacts, volcano eruptions, oceans rising and falling, whole continents moving, an endless, constant, violent change, colliding, buckling to make mountains over millions of years. Earth has survived everything in its time. It will certainly survive us. If all the nuclear weapons in the world went off at once and all the plants, all the animals died and the earth was sizzling hot for a hundred thousand years, life would survive, somewhere: under the soil, frozen in Arctic ice. Sooner or later, when the planet was no longer inhospitable, life would spread again. The evolutionary process would begin again. It might take a few billion years for life to regain its present variety. Of course, it would be very different from what it is now, but the earth would survive our folly, only we would not. If the ozone layer gets thinner, ultraviolet radiation sears the earth, so what? Ultraviolet radiation is good for life. It's powerful energy. It promotes mutation, change. Many forms of life will thrive with more UV radiation. Many others will die out. Do you think this is the first time that's happened? Think about oxygen. Necessary for life now, but oxygen is actually a metabolic poison, a corrosive glass, like fluorine. When oxygen was first produced as a waste product by certain plant cells some three billion years ago, it created a crisis for all other life on earth. Those plants were polluting the environment, exhaling a lethal gas. Earth eventually had an atmosphere incompatible with life. Nevertheless, life on earth took care of itself. In the thinking of the human being a hundred years is a long time. A hundred years ago we didn't have cars, airplanes, computers or vaccines. It was a whole different world, but to the earth, a hundred years is nothing. A million years is nothing. This planet lives and breathes on a much vaster scale. I was traveling an hour south of Salem, Oregon on I-5 at 10 pm in the spring of 1982. I kept seeing green and pink lights in my rear view mirror, and when it hit me what I had been seeing, I pulled off the road and got out of the car. All around me, the sky was filled with swirling, dancing waves of pink and green light. I felt elated, as if I were slightly high, and for a few minutes I was enveloped in the magic of the moment. But I had to two more hours of driving before arriving home, and would be missed, so I reluctantly got back on my way, grateful for the opportunity to not only see, but experience the northern lights. Haven't seen them since, but will never forget the feeling.

I was living in Quebec in 1989 when the electricity went out. When the electric company said it was due to "solar flares" we all collectively rolled our eyes, thinking: "sure, it was the sun's fault that you can't run an electric company". Fortunately it was in the summer and only lasted for half a day.
But ten years later a freak January storm brought down power lines all over Quebec and some cities had no electricity for 3-4 weeks. Having millions of people without heat and power in the middle of Canadian winter was no joke. Thankfully there were very few deaths, as electric companies all over North America sent repair crews to help us. But if all of North America's electric grid went down one winter due to a solar flare, I shudder to think how bad it would be.

comment_by: Robert Walker - fact check for Doomsday Debunked
comment_text:
2025 is just the next solar max. It just means a higher chance of solar storms. The spacex satellites weren't in their final orbit they were in low oribt in the process of being launched. It's a bit puzzling that SpaceX launched them in those conditions when the atmosphere was too thick for their launch.

If there is a big solar storm it would NOT do anything to consumer electronics - it's not like a lightning strike which can damage things plugged to the grid. The voltage changes for a solar storm can only build up over tens to hundreds of kilometers and the only equipment affected are the big transformers connected to long distance powerlines to step the power up / down to the voltages we use at home. However they have been hardened a lot since 1989 and the Quebec powercut wouldn't happen today.

And - powercuts are quite common especially in rural areas and it is possible to survive a few hours without your washing machines etc, just postpone it to the next day. Hospitals have uninterruptible power supplies that automatically switch to fuel powered generators as soon as the power goes off.

The 2.6 trillion dollars hadn't taken account of the more resilient modern transformers - also it is very dependent on the underlying ground. The US has losses every year of around $100 billion from powercuts. Costs might be similar to a large hurricane - but most of it wouldn't be noticed by customers because the equipment is triply redundant.

Quebec was vulnerable because the ground below it is resistive - only some places in the US are vulnerable in that way - and you also need long power transmission cables of tens to hundreds of kilometers - and then the transformers are triply redundant and they would give particular attnetion to the places most at risk.

I go into some of this here:

https://debunkingdoomsday.quora.com/What-would-the-effects-be-of-a-major-solar-storm-Short-term-local-power-cuts-for-hours-not-widespread-blackout-for-mo

More on the SpaceX satellites.

Starlink satellites start in a low orbit and then they go into a higher orbit under their own power.

What happened with the spaceX satellites is just that the 40 spacex starlink satellites - didn't get to go into high orbit.

They went edge on to avoid de-orbiting but they then couldn't move back to normal configuration and fell out of orbit.

Even in that “safe-mode,” the increase in atmospheric drag was too much, and many of the satellites were unable to leave the mode to raise their orbit, and “up to 40 of the satellites will reenter or already have reentered the Earth’s atmosphere.”
https://spaceexplored.com/2022/02/08/geomagnetic-storm-costs-spacex-40-freshly-launched-starlink-satellites/
It's a bit of a puzzle why SpaceX didn't just postpone the launch as this was all predictable or should have been.

https://earthsky.org/space/40-starlink-satellites-doomed-by-geomagnetic-storm/

I'm not sure about the actual physics of the electrical system being affected.
Dianna... Love your videos, but there's very little physics of electricity in this one. Explain please! Let's the see the math of the magnetic lines inducing the voltage that cause damage. You can sum it up in a couple sentences! I was kinda off put by the doomsday-ness of your video but no science to support the damage forecast. You said, "x trillion dollars damage!" with the look of a scared child instead of a scientific mind that questions theories and blanket statements.

Magnetic field lines that cross electrical wires induce a voltage. Does the solar wind cause the earth's magnetic field to shift, and thus there is induced electrical current generated in the millions of kilometres of wires? ...even then, every transformer along the way is a step down transformer, EXCEPT for the step up transformers at the generator. Those are only meters long. Not kilometres-long. So if additional voltage is applied to the high voltage lines, it's stepped down. The major transmission lines carry 500kv, which is then stepped down to 14,400v at the the sub stations. Then at the housing, it's stepped down again to 120/240 or 120/208. Going from 500,000v down to 240v is a 2000:1 step down in voltage. So to increase enough voltage to cause damage would take an increase on the transmission lines of like 20,000 volts! To get 300 volts, where there was 240, is an increase of 125,000 Volts on the transmission lines!!! When lightning strikes transmission lines, it only occasionally causes big damage, and it's on the order of the megavolt addition. So... Yeah, the sun's big, but 20kv is a lot of voltage to add. Even for a thousand kilometres of wire. A LOT. Especially by a slow moving magnetic field. I might be wrong. I don't know about how the magnetic field of the earth is affected. Maybe it bumps around enough to cause a lot of volts? Dunno. But I don't think it's that much.

Someone's going to say, what about the watts or amps? Nope. Amps are decided by the resistance in the lines. If there's enough voltage to blow out the insulators, around the lines, there will be a short, and then current goes through the roof. But the current goes to ground by the shortest means necessary. Sooo... 20kv to increase by 10 volts on the customer side. Maybe it's enough to cause something get damaged... But not my fridge or dishwasher. Maybe my TV and computer... But then not if there's a surge protector installed.
I'm totally open to being corrected! Please... someone take this up and explain.

I actually understood the neon sign bit thanks to my chemistry class. Electrons orbiting a nucleus can exist in different states of energy. As the energy level of an electron increases, it shifts to a wider orbit around the nucleus since its increased energy allows it to partially overcome the force I’m forgetting the name of that keeps the electrons close to the nucleus. However, higher the energy level an electron is inhabiting, the more unstable it is. An electron can’t exist outside of its default state closer to the nucleus indefinitely, so eventually it returns to a lower orbit and releases the energy it previously absorbed as a result.
This released energy takes the form of heat and light. Hence, when neon signs are given an electrical charge, the unstable position of the electrons causes them to repeatedly emit heat and light before becoming charged again.
Resulting in a fancy lightbulb.
Although I don’t have my notes from that class with me at the moment, so if I’m wrong please correct me.

I commend your presentation of this item as extremely important as most geo-cosmic scientists do not like discussing solar cycles and its effects on the earth's weather patterns and would like to add a little more to the discussion. There are actually two radiation projection periods as the sun's magnetic poles rotate, (not switch) over two 11 year cycles.

Each pole to pole change, as observed and recorded by variations in the sun spot activity or number of sunspots as far back as the 15th century, give rise to solar maxima (winds) when each pole faces the solar elliptic and heat, sunspots and CMEs at their maximum when the poles are perpendicular to the solar elliptic. While generally solar maxima (winds) produced high levels of sustained radiation to produce the auroras and induction into copper infrastructure like electrical grid systems that may cause transformer burnouts, it is when the poles are vertical that the earth receives the more intense heat radiation.

CMEs occurring when the sunspot activity is at it maximum when the sun's magnetic poles are vertical or at 90 degrees to the solar elliptic (planets) and will increase in intensity as the solar activity increases up to the 24th century.

During solar maxima, the radiation is more intense but the heat generated and emitted towards the planet is less, causing less evaporation of the surface water, therefore less rainfall and a period of droughts. At the height of sunspot activity (45degrees later), the increase in heat from direct radiation, sunspots and CMEs, increases the evaporation of earth's surface water producing greater rainfall and flooding, sometimes severe, for either of the events. This cycle of wet and dry or flooding and droughts is easily observable around the world, especially in countries like Australia and can be observed in your chart for cycles 11, 22, 44 and 88 years.

If you extend and extrapolate the graph out further it will show up a 1408 year cycle which will take the current earth weather patterns severity to the mid 24th century before it starts to wind down again. This cycle is quite observable in historic records back to the Maunder Minimum in 17th century, Vikings in Greenland in 10th century and many other historic changes in civilizations recorded back to early Persians.

You could easily explain transformer failures a lot better than that.  Transformer can have voltage across their windings, only as long as their cores can be changing their magnetic field.  Carrying alternating current, the cycles don't last long enough for the changing core magnetic fields to ever swing strong enough, in either direction, to saturate the iron core, before the voltage direction reverses and changes the magnetic field in the opposite direction.  But Aurora can generate DC or very low frequency voltages in the power grid, that saturate the transformers' magnetic cores.  Once that happens, their windings are just pieces of copper wire connected across the voltage of the grid.  Boom!

Solar storms and geomagnetic activity pose no health risks? I think that deserves a second look. A very interesting look I might add.
Abstract

Alignment of serial epidemiological, physiological, including electrocardiographic data with variations in galactic cosmic rays, geomagnetic activity, and atmospheric pressure suggests the possibility of links among these physical environmental variations and health risks, such as myocardial infarctions and ischemic strokes, among others. An increase in the incidence of myocardial infarction in association with magnetic storms, reported by several investigators from Russia, Israel, Italy and Mexico, accounts in Minnesota for a 5% (220 cases/year) increase in mortality during years of maximal solar activity by comparison with years of minimal solar activity. Magnetic storms are also found to decrease heart rate variability (HRV), indicating a possible mechanism since a reduced HRV is a prognostic factor for coronary artery disease and myocardial infarction. Longitudinal electrocardiographic monitoring for a week or much longer spans in different geographic locations, notably in the auroral oval, further suggests that the decrease in HRV affects spectral regions other than that around 3.6 s (0.15-0.40 Hz), reportedly associated with the parasympathetic nervous system. Differences in some associations are observed from solar cycle to solar cycle, and as a function of solar cycle stage, a finding resolving controversies. Coordinated physiological and physical monitoring, the scope of an international project on the Biosphere and the Cosmos, seeks reference values for a better understanding of environmental effects on human health and for testing the merit of space weather reports that could prompt countermeasures in space and on earth. Physiological data being collected systematically worldwide and morbidity/mortality statistics from causes such as myocardial infarction and stroke constitute invaluable data bases for assessing changes within the physiological range, for detecting environmental effects and for recognizing endogenous as well as exogenous disease-risk syndromes. Timely and timed intervention may then be instituted to lower risk, in preference to exclusive current focus on treating overt disease. These chronodiagnostics are particularly important for those venturing into regions away from hospitals, such as astronauts in space."

I'd argue for a correction to replace "more infrastructure" with "better infrastructure" - smaller less interconnected grids IMO are a better path forward in the future. Higher resilience due to less centralized generation and vulnerable/expensive distribution, and less opportunity to dump the "waste heat" into our atmosphere (as of this writing, about 1/3 of all energy produced goes out a cooling tower).

Think about it - during a hemisphere's summer months when sun is plentiful, PV and solar heat can meet the needs of a given building. During a hemisphere's winter months when the sun is less available, a combined heat and power system can burn natural gas locally (starting with digester gas from sewage treatment and landfill reclamation) and you get the benefit of a heat output from an electricity generation source to heat the building while converting a more harmful form of greenhouse gas (CH4) into a less harmful type (CO2). Extra electricity can be used to drive a heat pump for additional heat rather than storing in another form - because you should be using a dual-mode heat pump anyway (air conditioners we are all familiar with are single mode). Naysayers will claim solar thermal heat doesn't work well, but that's probably just down to poor system design - in North America, it works even in Canada and Alaska when done right: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eJMOM01NA40

Abundance and "out-of-sight-out-of-mind" generation results in waste. If you had to generate your own power and it was harder to do so than flipping a switch and paying a few cents an hour - you wouldn't waste so much of it, and the less energy one uses, the less waste heat there is as well. Less usage will lead to lower total CO2 output, but nobody really wants to talk about lifestyle changes.

The satellites falling due to the expansion of the upper atmosphere is relatively normal, the only reason they fell was due to an unforeseen error by SpaceX. SpaceX put their satellites into very low (decaying) orbits before boosting themselves up to higher orbits where they deploy and become functional, due to the increased resistance from the hotter upper atmosphere they put them in their "safe mode" where they change their attitude to become more aerodynamic and create less drag, but they couldn't take them out of this safe mode so they de-orbited.

The solar storm didn't knock them out of orbit, the solar storm prevented them from reaching orbit and trapped them in the denser atmosphere.
The whole reason for this initial very low orbit is so that if there are technical problems with the satellites, their orbit will quickly decay and the satellite will burn up during re-entry and reduce the chances of broken satellites being trapped in orbit for thousands of years.

If you put any satellite in this low orbit, it will quickly fall back to Earth, whether there is a solar storm or not, again the solar storm prevented them from reaching their targeted orbit.

comment_by: Touch. Me. I Will Turn You On
comment_text:
Current solar physics intern here studying CMEs! I'm actually going to school for space weather as well! I have to say, great video, and I'm very glad you made it! This was really factual and better than 99% of the videos I see on YouTube on solar flares and CMEs. 7:32 is such a great idea of what the aurora is "doing," and something I have used to explain the processes in the magnetosphere and energy transfer to newcomers in the field.

One criticism, G1 is really nothing for power grids, and unless you're a satellite operator you probably don't need to worry. Even G5 is not a big deal, we've hit G5 without major power grid issues before... but the problem is that after G5 there's no way to "categorize" solar storms based on KPI alone, you would have to look at other measurements like DST, AE, etc. It's like an F5 tornado - you don't know the difference between a strong F5 and a weak F5 just by saying, "it's an F5." The 1989 storm is a great example of how GICs (ground-induced currents) can cause transformers to become overloaded, burning them out if they're "wet" transformers (older transformers that have water contaminated in the oil, creating boiling water bubbles that shred paper insulation between coils, sparking fires).

It should be mentioned that a DC power grid (carrying Direct Current) would NOT be affected by a solar superstorm. China and Brazil both have DC power grids in part of their respective countries. The shorter wires of local grids are not likely to be damaged, either. The reason why AC power grids are affected is the long wires get low frequency currents, similar to DC, induced into them by temporary shifts to Earth's own magnetic field (the geomagnetic storms), caused by the intense solar wind during a solar superstorm. Direct Current is bad for Alternating Current transformers. Until recent years there was no good alternative to AC when electrical power had to be moved long distances, because high voltages have to be used. Now the technology exists to interconvert the high voltages between AC and DC on the power grid systems, and DC is now even more efficient than AC, but the grid owners, being concerned with short-term profits, have not bothered to convert the long lines to DC. Waiting to convert is a very bad idea.

The connection between the loss of the spacex satellites and CME wasn't quite correct. The heating from the sun was abnormal at the time, resulting in an actual reduction in density of the atmosphere, but expansion of the atmosphere beyond expectations. This meant there was more atmosphere higher up into space than expected, causing excessive drag and loss of speed of the satellites - pulling them out of orbit.

One of the biggest problems is that since the Carrington Event, our Earth has lost about 20% of our magnetic field strength and it continues to rapidly (and exponentially) decrease in field intensity. The Earth's magnetic field is its main shield against Solar and cosmic events/energies. That means, it wouldn't even take a Carrington level CME or combo Solar event to send us all back into the pioneer days.

It is truly not a matter of if, but when at this point, especially as the field gets weaker and weaker. The entire grid system would need billions of dollars of upgrade and protection, and even that wouldn't create a sure certainty of these not being taken completely out.

And Solar activity absolutely affects humans and human health on multiple levels and in various different ways. There is A LOT of scientific literature about that. For some examples, vehicular accidents are noted to increase during periods of intense Solar activity, heart attacks and strokes go up, mental illness issues increase, and anecdotally speaking, I almost always know via body symptoms, when there has been at least X class, Earth directed flares. Basically I get super tired and brain foggy out of no where, and sometimes more irritable than usual and I'm a pretty chill/laid back person for the most part. If it is strong enough, I also get a headache, of which I'm not prone to normally at all. There are even research studies that have found a correlation between collective events of human violence and increased Solar activity (flares, CME's, large sunspots, strong solar wind, etc).

Not so fun fact... Remember those anomalous very well preserved via freezing mammoths that are roughly around 12, 000 years old or so? The only phenomenon that can explain their unusual deaths and preservation is something like a Solar micro nova. We're talking a Solar event that makes the Carrington one look weak. Why do I say this? First, you have to understand how anomalous their preservation is. We know that these, before their demise, were munching on flowers and grass, which very strongly implies that it most likely was no colder than 40* F or so, and more likely to be 50* and above.

Mammoths have a shite ton of thermal mass. If you try to freeze a previously alive mammoth with normal methods and temps, even well below freezing, you're going to get flesh mush because of how much thermal mass there is. This is because large water crystals form and freeze degrading the flesh. It had to drop to around -120* or more, and stay that way for at least a couple days, for these to freeze as well as they did. Remember, previous to their demise, it was no colder than 40*. We're talking a some 160* (at least) sudden and semi sustained drop in temps.

There is only one mechanism known that could possibly do this. If there was a sufficiently strong Solar event where the Sun spewed not just a massive amount of plasma but also significant matter in our direction (there are Stars observed to have recurrent micro novas that spew straight up dense matter btw), the combo would rip away large chunks of the Earth's atmosphere on the Sun facing side of the earth. When the rest of the Earth's atmosphere rushes back into to re-equalize, you would get a Boyles Law type super cooling from the gas pressure differentials created. Here's the interesting thing though about these Mammoths, and which further supports an enormously powerful Solar event: These Mammoths did not die by freezing, but by what seems to be massive, violent flooding. For example, clear signs of asphyxiation AND things like their massive pelvic bones being ripped out and twisted. Mangled up whilst drowning. There is not much in nature that can so mangle a Mammoth, except massive, violent flooding or dropping from large heights.

Meaning, what happened first, before the super cooling, was a super heating and melting of all those massive glaciers that were around them and presumably to the north of them whilst they were munching away on flowers and grass. So first you have a super heating leading to massive flooding, and then you have the super cooling right after. They had no chance. You can't outrun this stuff.

The Carrington event, which would disable technology for months, was actually medium size in view of the sun's longer cycles. CMEs that size happen about once every 150-200 years. Bigger ones, such as the Carolingian event, happen about every 1200-1500 years. A Carolingian size blast would put us down for years. Bigger ones yet happen about every 3000 years. We don't even know how much worse that would be. And the biggest of all may well coincide with the 12ky catastrophe cycle, which is large enough to cause extinctions and trigger the next ice age. It would obliterate all electrical systems. We're near the end of each of those cycles. Bolster the infrastructure? Yes. But stock up on everything you'll need to live without electricity indefinitely. And learn survival skills. Just in case.

How do you figure that 'small'-electronics wouldn't be as affected? The chips used in 'small'-electronics have some of the smallets geometries and are much more susceptible to microscopic arc-over and even with the internal shielding could still reach charge-levels that would arc from the shield to the circuitry leads (because there would be a huge potential difference and you do NOT have a perfect Faraday-cage geometry--ESD and EMI testing has born this out) especially where internal-wiring exits the shield to go to somewhere else.
Additionally, any device plugged in for charging would probably be duck-soup.

When you mention the loss of power for months or longer I don't think people really understand what that would do. Most cities would have serious water issues. Anyone living in a multi story or high-rise building would not have water without power. The water supply is pumped up into the holding tanks in the upper floors to supply the water and pressure for the dwellings below. No power, no water in those tanks and no water for the residents. Not to mention the issues with elevators. Major cities will become major evacuation sites as in some cases millions will need to be moved out in a matter of days. The same issue is true in many residential areas. If you can see your towns water tower, it doesn't fill itself. Pumps fill it and then it supplies the pressure to push the water through the local lines. So people in those areas will not have running water either and be dependent on potable water being delivered. This alone could be one of the biggest parts of the disaster. We worry about our reaction to losing electronic conveniences and com-sats during an event like this. Life giving water may be the thing that really hurts humanity and causes the most issues worldwide.

Great video!  It's an extremely simplified version of what actually happens, that's what I like about this channel.  The average YouTube watcher can understand it (not meaning to be condescending.)  Back a couple of hundred years ago someone discovered that moving a magnet next to a wire induces an electric current.  I won't get off into the weeds about who and when.  That's what happens when a solar storm hits us.  As she mentioned, the storm of particles smashes into our magnetic field, most of the energy goes into compressing the sun-facing side of that magnetic field and diverting the charged particles to the poles where they smash into atoms in the upper atmosphere.  That HUGE moving (smashed) magnetic field induces current into the thousands of miles of copper and aluminum wire crossing the continents.  This causes super high voltages and currents to be induced and overloads the transformers which can cost hundreds of thousands of dollars and take months or years to replace.  We should know anywhere from days to hours that a super-storm is coming (because the light gets here before the solar wind does) and be able to "unplug" the power stations from the grid before the storm hits us and I believe that's the only way to save the grid -- shut it down for the short period of time it takes for the storm to pass.  Sure, everyone will be without electricity for hours but it's better than weeks or years...  Again   GREAT VIDEO.

The only thing the KP really measures is how far south or north you can see the event. There are a ton of other things that drive an inpact, the solar wind, the density of the solar wind, the temperature of the wind, the magnetic charge (the Bz), and the amount of stored energy in the stream (the Bt). Then, we watch earthbound magtnometors, and know how it is affecting out magnetic field. All of these are "forecasted" by the KP, and it updates every 3 hours. A high KP is not a guarantee of an good Aurora event

You cannot predict a Carrington event as it is very very very rare, so much so that we have never observed one since we have started modern monitoring of the Sun.      You need #1. for Earth to be in the path of the Storm which in itself is very rare and #2 the storm MUST be in a configuration where multiple Solar Storms are launched at Earth one after the other each as powerful or more so, this is very rare and only a few times have Satellites picked up on such a configuration and they were all far weaker than the Carrington event.    The reason the Carrington event was so powerful was the each phase of he Solar Storm further weakened the ionosphere, including damage when the ionosphere was pulled away from earth and then re-bounded, causing more damage on the re-bound than by the first impact of the storm.    After multiple storms, in short period of time, the final few rounds caused the well documented event.   This is an extremely rare event and we have never seen one blasted out from the Sun either directed at earth or in any other direction.   The likelihood of such an event is impossible to predict until it occurs again and even then you need some sort of baseline so multiple such events need to occur and yet we may not see one again in hundreds of years.

For small perspective on how damaging loss of electricity can be - here in South Africa our central power delivery company, Eskom, has been struggling for the last couple of years to ensure stable electricity delivery to all. Much of it simply due to astounding mismanagement and allowing infrastructure to deteriorate. So when components in some of the power stations go down there is just not enough electricity to meet demand and a system called “Load shedding” is implemented. Basically this cuts power to neighborhoods for 2 - 4 hour periods at a time on a schedule. Basically, the worse the supply, the more frequent and severe the powercuts. Now this does not affect the grid infrastructure itself, but the economic loss of businesses unable to do business due to lack of electricity has been quite staggering. Now these are controlled and announced electricity cuts. I cannot begin to imagine what an unannounced global issue like a super storm will have.

FYI, many folks don’t realize that when the first U.S. space station Skylab re-entered back in July of 1979 it was due to increased solar activity. The increased solar activity bombarding the earth caused the atmosphere to expand thus causing more atmospheric drag on Low Earth Orbit objects such as Skylab. And since Skylab didn’t have any boosters installed, due to cost cutting, NASA couldn’t boost the lab higher in orbit to keep it from re-entering.

The atmosphere literally became thinner (lower in viscosity)(lower in density) because it was heated by the solar wind. This caused an increase in volume. This means atmospheric friction at 120 km. increased even though the density of the atmosphere fell.

The atmosphere got thicker (larger from top to bottom) because it got thinner (lower in density).

Current solar physics intern here studying CMEs! I'm actually going to school for space weather as well! I have to say, great video, and I'm very glad you made it! This was really factual and better than 99% of the videos I see on YouTube on solar flares and CMEs. 7:32 is such a great idea of what the aurora is "doing," and something I have used to explain the processes in the magnetosphere and energy transfer to newcomers in the field.

One criticism, G1 is really nothing for power grids, and unless you're a satellite operator you probably don't need to worry. Even G5 is not a big deal, we've hit G5 without major power grid issues before... but the problem is that after G5 there's no way to "categorize" solar storms based on KPI alone, you would have to look at other measurements like DST, AE, etc. It's like an F5 tornado - you don't know the difference between a strong F5 and a weak F5 just by saying, "it's an F5." The 1989 storm is a great example of how GICs (ground-induced currents) can cause transformers to become overloaded, burning them out if they're "wet" transformers (older transformers that have water contaminated in the oil, creating boiling water bubbles that shred paper insulation between coils, sparking fires).

Actually it appears that the Carrington event wasn't the most powerful geomagnetic storm in recorded history only one of the stronger ones which was much more notable as the CME associated with it was observed the strongest one was likely the one 13 years later in 1872 based on . But the last big solar superstorm comparable to the Carrington event was in 1921. Additionally thanks to tree rings and ice cores we now know of some storms which appear to have made the Carrington event and those like it look tiny in comparison being at least some 10 to 20 times stronger in the case of an extreme event in 775. Other super Carrington events which were somewhat weaker are known from 660BCE and 995, with events comparable to the storm of 775 having been identified around 7176 BCE and 5259 BCE. In other words these geomagnetic storms are far more common than we used to think.

Also as a fun fact about geomagnetic storms it turns out the Sun isn't the only thing which can produce them as superflares from young "nearby" magnetars in the Large Magellanic Cloud or Milky Way are also powerful enough to induce geomagnetic storms such as the event on March 5th 1979 caused by a magnetar within LMC N49 known as SGR 0525-66 , another two events originating from within the milky way from SGR1900+14 which struck Earth on August 27th 1998 and SGR 1806-20 which struck Earth on December 27th 2004. As the closest of these events was only several tens of kiloparsecs away (~40,000 light years) and were able to induce geomagnetic storms comparable to weak CMEs from our Sun it indicates these are truly extremely energetic flare events. In fact we have been able to observe such flares from extragalactic sources at Mega parsec distances though thankfully without geomagnetic storms and these flares may even be linked to at least some of the events known as Fast Radio Bursts according to observations by Chime raising truly alarming prospects about how powerful such flare events might be from magnetars far closer than tens of kiloparsecs from a planet especially as evidence suggests magnetars burn out the extreme magnetic fields that power such events within around 10,000 years. We are talking about flares that come from 40 to 50 thousand light years away but are still powerful enough to induce weak geomagnetic storms on Earth... That is F-ing insane and if FRB's are linked to these flares as seems likely then there are examples out there so powerful that faint radio echoes can be seen from giga parsec distances. The power of nature is is incomprehensibly awe inspiring.


Regarding the Space X satellites falling out of orbit one important detail missed is that atmospheric gravity-buoyancy waves have been shown to serve as the counterbalancing force to counteract the inflation of Earth's thermosphere due to solar activity (aka these waves induce cooling in the thermosphere) Early 2021 when the flare hit Earth the Northern hemisphere was experiencing a strong Sudden Stratospheric Warming Event which cuts off the coupling of these waves and the upper atmosphere as these waves dampen out in the stratosphere instead of propagating into the mesosphere and thermosphere meaning the Earth's thermosphere cooling response is severely impaired meaning the rate of cooling is greatly slowed down. This meant that the normal atmospheric expansion compensation methods used by low Earth orbit satellite operators didn't work well. I recommend looking up work by Erdal Yiggit which looks into these effects after showing that the effects of these waves can't be neglected in the upper atmosphere thanks to the effects momentum conservation and energy conservation induce on these waves amplitudes as the atmospheric density decreases.

Worth noting that while major solar storms are not uncommon, Earth is a tiny percentage of where the sun can actually hit. It's like firing a rifle in a random direction and wondering if you're gonna hit the goldfish in its little bowl. Direct hits and near misses (near enough that they actually cause issues) are bad, but they're rare just by virtue of Earth being such a small target.

Personally the scariest thing I find about all of this is that while all of the civil systems go down, many modern militaries are going to be just fine. At some point in the cold war, people realized that a nuclear bomb detonated in orbit over an area would create a huge pulse of radiation that would disrupt electronics - this is the easy way of making a weaponized EMP. And since it's an excellent way of creating incredibly widespread disruption, it was considered a likely component of a first strike, so various militaries who faced the issue of trying to figure out how to make WWIII survivable started including the necessary electromagnetic shielding into most of their equipment. Ideally this would be a good thing for helping with the recovery from a solar event like this, but given the degree to which it would disrupt civilian life, we'd likely have anarchy, which would likely result in martial law to impose order, and historically militaries that are given the power to police a country tend not to give that power up easily.

Ideally all of the infrastructure we rely on would have the same electromagnetic hardening the military uses - it's not exactly difficult to set up for things that don't transmit/receive radio signals, and it's not a military secret. It's just a decent sized layer of metal shielding. But covering the entire power grid in a layer of electromagnetic shielding would be exceedingly expensive because there's a LOT of power grid to cover. And this version of "ideal" is ignoring that.

Perhaps a better solution would be to have strategic reserves of equipment such that you could get the majority of the grid back online in the handful of days it takes to swap out all of those parts rather than the years of having to manufacture everything from scratch (and possibly having to deal with the issues of getting the factory and various shipping systems up and running before you can even start manufacturing and distributing the necessary equipment.

Not to undermine the potential severity of a storm... But these are generally events that we literally see coming, and typically have the better part of a week to prep for. And the height of a storm where it would be damaging at ground level is generally a 2-8 hour window (though elevated levels can last a week), and is statistically likely to impact a major population center for only a portion of that time as the world keeps spinning.

Yes, if one somehow caught us off guard, and happened to hit a major population center at 9am on a work day, then it could be absolutely devistating, with decades of recovery time!
But this is highly unlikely to happen. More likely than not we will see it coming 3 days ahead of time, and have plenty of warning to shut down equipment and unplug through the worst of the storm. Still not great. But probably a larger security risk of an enemy attack during that time than any major threat to the grid or the few things that silly humans keep plugged into it.

More importantly, as time goes on and we bury power lines, and have more decentralized power distribution, and move more communications to terrestrial fiber networks instead of slow low bandwidth sattelites, and have battery backups for critical systems, we are becoming ever more hardened against such a threat.
The problem isn't miles long city lines that attach your home to your distribution hub. The issue is the tens and hundreds of miles of straight lines that make up the larger network. Disconnect those, and most cities, especially cities with buried lines, will be able to ride out a storm without having to worry about a blackout unless it is particularly strong. This would leave smaller cities and rural areas without power... Which is inconvenient... But would minimize major economic problems.

So is it a problem? Yes. Will a big one hit within my lifetime? Likely more than one. Will it affect my small corner of the world when it happens? Not super likely. Will we not see it coming and unleash the apacolipse upon the world? No, no it will not. It will be a day long curiosity like an eclipse that will create a lot of buzz! But not likely life altering beyond a weird day.

Very cool explanation. Here's the real 'Climate Change' factor. If you want to do long term weather forecasting, consider which year of the Solar Cycle you're in. Start with going back 11 years and you'll have a pretty good prediction of what to expect in the forthcoming season. Similarly you can move forward in time through the corresponding year of the cycle and bingo, you know what to plan for, eg. droughts, floods, fires, good rain etc. Each forecast is area specific .... The current cycle started in 2020 as far as I know. The previous cycle started in 2009, so current weather should correlate with 2011 if my hypothesis is correct. Obviously there will be variation as there are cosmic forces affecting the sun's solar cycle. Big weather systems seem to spin up after big solar storms. When the sun is relatively calm, year 9, 10 and 11 - expect massive droughts and fires. There may also be links with earthquakes and volcanic activity, though I haven't given this much thought.

Back in December 2004 (or 2005, I really don't remember which year), my dad and I flew from Raleigh, NC to Chicago, IL to visit family in nearby Michigan and then, of course, flew back home Raleigh. We landed, gathered our luggage and picked up my car and headed home. This was around 10pm to 11pm. We were driving on the newly minted I-540 when my dad asked me "what is that glowing light in the sky? Is that the Northern Lights?" We were both confused a bit by this bright, green glowing phenomenon being seen at that latitude. But, we were able to confirm that it was indeed the Northern Lights. Aside from the rare sighting of the Aurora Borealis in Raleigh, NC, our confusion about what were witnessing stemmed from the fact that 99% of the time the Aurora is shown on TV, video or film it is a lie. A bit harsh, I know, but stay with me: Pretty much every time you see it the colors are moving and dancing across the sky. In reality, they don't do that, unless you film/video the Aurora over time and then play it back speeded up several times. The lights do move but in reality at a much slower pace than the puffy clouds in a blue sky on a windless day.

The spacex starlink satellites weren't lost directly because of solar winds. They decided to keep the satellites in a low profile configuration to protect them during the event. The satellites had been launched a day or two prior and so hadn't boosted into their typical higher orbit. The result was that the satellites orbits decayed due to being in more atmosphere than they were designed to be in so when they were told to come out of the low profile configuration, there was too much air resistance from the atmosphere at their altitude to allow them to shift into a configuration that would allow them to boost their orbits. As a result they couldn't raise their orbits and fell back to earth. This is why it only effected the 40 or so satellites from that launch not from the wider constellation.

This is why we have a manual pump for water from our well, a wood burning stove for heat (and hand tools to harvest the fuel), and grow food that does not require a functioning power grid to keep preserved.  The aspect of CME-induced power grid failure that we CAN'T prepare for on an individual basis is the zircalloy rods that currently repose in the cooling ponds beside each and every nuclear power station .. these fuel rods are too hot to put into dry storage (that takes five years of cooling) and require that water be constantly pumped in to replace evaporation losses.  Should those rods become exposed to air, they will burn - spreading {lethal levels of} radioactive ash downwind for several hundreds of kilometers.  The only thing keeping those pumps going at the moment?  A functioning power grid.

Most of the electric grid in the US has been hardened and is equipped with sensors and relays that open circuit breakers and switches automatically if voltage, current, or frequency excursions exceed limits.  This should isolate critical equipment from damage during external energy events like CME events.  It is unlikely that even severe solar events would cause permanent damage to most portions of the grid.  Jess

Modern transformers on the power grids have spark gap equipment attached as well as a lot of other equipment in the power substation specifically for dealing with lightening strikes as well as power surges from solar flares. The power lines stretched over the lands act like secondary windings on transformers so the solar flares which are high in electromagnetic energy induce much higher voltages on those lines than they normally experience. The spark gap equipment will bleed those high voltages directly to ground protecting the transformers. on the receiving ends of those power lines coming into a city or some other populated area that taps into the power grid.
It's true that in the past that there have been power outages due to transformers being blown up, or damaged by solar flares, but todays systems are equipped to deal with this, so no need to be a chicken little and run around in fear.

Neon and Aurora are not emitting light because "electrons fly off". Solar wind particles (aurora) or free electrons (neon light) will hit gas particles and transfer energy. This energy pushes electrons in the gas atom shell to a higher, unstable energy level. These electrons will fall back to the lower, stable energy level and emit the energy difference as a photon.

So in other words, a good plan would be to have a few necessary electronics (multiple radios, drives with survival information, a few computers with good entertainment programs and stuff to use for survival or communication, and a power supply setup of some sort) in a Faraday cage so you can survive easily. Also good replacement parts for your home utility systems.

To ease the tension, the reports of electronics frying come from time when fuses and circuit-breakers were not that common. Nowadays, you have multiple circuit protecting components in almost any device. Furthermore, most workplaces have UPS protected circuits - you can get those for your home computer as well. Important infrastructure (datacenters, hospitals but even hotels etc.) is backed up by diesel generators, they typically have enough fuel for a few days. Induction of current from the atmosphere would be almost exclusively limited to the grid itself, so once that is cut off from your circuit, the devices themselves do not pose much risk. Summed up, it would be troublesome, but not apocalyptic.
I think it's extremely important. More need to call out how little redundancy and backup equipment we have to repair our infrastructure.

Parts that are expensive to build and need months to create...under optimal conditions.  They were pushing for a spending plan to pre-build replacements for the items that are very difficult to replace and put them in storage near where they would be needed so the grid could be restored in hours or days and not months.  Didn't pass...yet we easily spend more than what was proposed on wasteful pork programs and pointless wars.
